title: Porting schedules (except convolutions) to C++
body:
## Operators
- [x] broadcast_min, broadcast_max
- [x] elementwise: identity, negative, log, left_shift, right_shift, clip, cast
- [x] reduction: sum, max, min, argmax, argmin
- [x] transforms: expand_dims, transpose, reshape, squeeze, concatenate, split
- [x] batch_norm_inference
- [x] binary_dense
- [x] dense
- [x] dilate
- [x] leaky_relu
- [x] flatten
- [x] scale_shift_nchw, scale_shift_nhwc
- [x] pad - add pad_value argument
- [x] global_pool, pool
- [x] softmax, log_softmax
- [x] pow, broadcast_pow
## Generic schedules
- [x] injective
- [x] _default_schedule
- [x] extern

## CUDA schedules
- [x] injective
- [x] dense
- [x] extern
- [x] pool, global_pool
- [x] reduce
- [x] softmax

## Other schedules
- [x] x86: binarize_pack, binary_dense
- [x] rocm: dense
- [x] x86: injective, default from #775

repo.name: tvm
repo.description: Open deep learning compiler stack for cpu, gpu and specialized accelerators

title: [PASS] StorageRewrite Fold Inplace op storage when possible
body:
Resolves https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/746

Detect pattern ```dst[index] = f(src[index])``` and fold src with dst when possible

Known limitation:

the current detection algorithm cannot handle the case when a location in an array is written multiple times. For example, the following program will pass the check, but we cannot make A and B to be the same array. 
```c++
A[0] = B[0] + 1
A[0] = B[0] + 1
```
The high-level code generator needs to ensure that the generated code only write each location of the target once. This is the case with the current schedule.

This limitation is documented in the comment

So this pass works fine for now. To enhance the safety, we might be able to use another pass to detect some sufficient condition when an array is written once in each location, which requires some work but can be useful to make it work for an arbitrary segment of IR.

title: [ROCM] MIOpen contrib for convolution kernels
body:
There are several differences with cudnn contrib:
* MIOpen compiles and caches kernel codes during runtime
* Compilation happens during mandatory miopenFindConvolutionForwardAlgorithm(...)
* miopenFindConvolutionForwardAlgorithm(...) runs a benchmark to find the best algo for the provided input. 
* To avoid running miopenFindConvolutionForwardAlgorithm on every extern call, I run it once during build time. Workspace is also setup during build time. 

I attached a test case which compares miopen output with TVM AMDGPU backend.
```
$ python test_miopen.py 
[22:50:44] src/contrib/miopen/conv_forward.cc:136: 	MIOpen Found 1 fwd algorithms, choosing miopenConvolutionFwdAlgoWinograd
[22:50:44] src/contrib/miopen/conv_forward.cc:139: 		0) miopenConvolutionFwdAlgoWinograd - time: 0.110878 ms, Memory: 0
/home/masa/project/dev/tvm/python/tvm/build_module.py:340: UserWarning: Specified target rocm, but cannot find device code, did you do bind?
  "Specified target %s, but cannot find device code, did you do bind?" % target)
Max abs diff: 4.19617e-05
```
@adityaatluri

title: Basic WebGL Backend
body:
### TLDR

Currently the following demo program runs and gets the correct result.

```python
from __future__ import absolute_import, print_function

import tvm
import numpy as np

n = tvm.var("n")
A = tvm.placeholder((n,), name='A')
B = tvm.placeholder((n,), name='B')
C = tvm.compute(A.shape, lambda i: A[i] + B[i], name="C")

s = tvm.create_schedule(C.op)
s[C].opengl()

fadd_gl = tvm.build(s, [A, B, C], "opengl", name="myadd")
print("------opengl code------")
print(fadd_gl.imported_modules[0].get_source(fmt="gl"))

ctx = tvm.opengl(0)
n = 10
a = tvm.nd.array(np.random.uniform(size=(n)).astype(A.dtype), ctx)
b = tvm.nd.array(np.random.uniform(size=(n)).astype(B.dtype), ctx)
c = tvm.nd.array(np.zeros((n), dtype=C.dtype), ctx)
fadd_gl(a, b, c)

np.testing.assert_allclose(c.asnumpy(), a.asnumpy() + b.asnumpy())
```

The corresponding fragment shader is

```glsl
#version 330 core
uniform sampler2D A;
uniform sampler2D B;
out float C;
void main() {
  ivec2 threadIdx = ivec2(gl_FragCoord.xy);
  C = (texelFetch(A, ivec2(threadIdx.x, 0), 0).r + texelFetch(B, ivec2(threadIdx.x, 0), 0).r);
}
```

## Current Status

### OpenGL Tensor Storage
- We store tensors in OpenGL textures.
- No matter what dimensions a tensor has, we always store it in a 2D texture with height=1.
- The reason we are not using 1D textures is that `texelFetch` in GLSL only supports 2D textures.
- We support uint{8,16,32}, int{8,16,32} and float32 textures.

### OpenGL Schedule
- We added an `opengl` schedule, which basically fuses all dimensions into one and binds that single dimension to threadIdx.x.

### Codegen
- We haven't changed lowering at all. When the IR says `Store(buffer, index)` and the buffer happens to be the output texture, we check that index must be `threadIdx.x`, and emit code to output a pixel.
- The codegen part has only been started. We will go through all the AST nodes as our next step.

### Task Items
- <del>Remove the dependency on glfw and glad.</del> Emscripten supports glfw. Glad removed.
- <del>Investigate emscripten.</del> Runtime runnable.
- <del>Support other types than float.</del> Done.
- <del>Use full RGBA channels.</del> Not critical now.
- <del>Don't let height always be 1. The reason is that OpenGL textures have stupid size limitations. For example, you can have a 2500x2500 2D texture but not a 6250000x1 2D texture. One possible way is just let height be the maximum supported value.</del> Not critical now.
- Go through the AST to properly do codegen.
- <del>Don't fuse reduction.</del> Gemm runnable.
- <del>Fix argument name generation.</del> Done.
